children.subject: I used to believe in Beaker’s position, until one of my internships reneged on me. It seems like a good move for you to renege, even at the expense of your personal connections. Do what makes you happy.
thanks for the response, both of you. Poet, can I ask why an internship reneged on you? no worries if you don't want to share, but I am also taking this possibility into consideration.
Reneging is not moral or immoral. Choose the best opportunities you have. The companies wouldn't think twice about firing you or withdrawing your offer, like last summer
Reneging is always not nice, regardless of it's by Employer or Employee.
It might not be nice but it's a business. Don't take it personal either way. And put yourself first.

As I stated above, it is a business. And our world is based on laws, not morality. So as long as the movement is legal, you may do it. But also no one can deny breaking a promise is not nice, so I personally don't encourage downplaying the reneging.

yea tbh I'm not concerned about the business aspect at all, I know they would drop me if they needed to. I am just more worried about how the actual people at the company will see me than the company itself (I also realize that while it's not nice, I need to do what's going to be best for me.)

@Scale, my internship was canceled last summer due to corona. They didn't think twice about dropping me, nor did they even give me an interview when the company got back on its feet. Clear lack of care for their employees. Of course all companies are different, but the lesson I learned is not to be too loyal or to worry about "losing opportunities," because those are scare tactics used by companies to get you to do what they want. By the way, congrats on the dream offer! :)

Adding on, this is why there are websites like Team Blind and levels.fyi where people are so transparent about their salaries because companies (obviously not all) routinely lowball their employees and get away with it. In addition, companies like Amazon are notorious for their PIP culture where managers have to fire x% of people every year regardless if they are performing well or not. Ultimately, companies have their own interests in mind, and you should too.

I wish I don't sound too condescending. Given I am also a student with no much power and establishment, my words are also inevitable to be lack of credibility. I am an outspoken person, so I sincerely apologize if my words offend you.

I have personally found reneging as a bad behavior morally, especially given the fact you have signed the offer and accept certain social-binding convention. But judging other people purely based on one single case and abstract morality is always not appropriate; after all, there are so many other factors that can reshape people's minds and force others to make a new decision. If the new company is really your dream company, and you believe it will be a better fit for you than the old company be, reneging probably will better off both you and the old company.

Bearing some cold words from the old company is inevitable and reasonable; after all, as I said above, I personally hold a strong faith against reneging. Will reneging affect your future careers? I personally think in this fast-paced and competitive world, your old company people will be upset by your decision, but they probably won't try to ruin your career, since this kind of revenge is just so petty and childish. Is that possible that someday in your future career, you run across an important figure who has remembered your renege and subjectively gives you a bad comment? Everything is possible, but you may decide the probability and bear some risks.

It's not uncommon that people renege. Some people just change their minds. Some people just encounter a surprising occasion. Some people are realistic and juggle with offers to ensure a backup and maximized achievement. As long as they don't breach the legal terms, they probably won't receive many "penalty points". So please make sure your internship offer doesn't have any legal binding terms you need to follow. Is it moral to do that? Probably not. But our world is using the laws, not subjective moral standards. Companies themselves also fire people if it's legally feasible.

tl;dr Your reason is not a bad reason. But reneging is also bad behavior. But if you decide to do it, more than likely you will be fine. Please talk nice to your old company, after all reneging is not nice.

The above statement is not legal advice, health advice, life advice of any kind. The writer won't take any responsibility for the words if there are any consequences.

history.content: If you know that you don't want to work with that company anymore, better to tell your manager now and potentially damage your relationships then doing so 1-2 years down the line.

hello! I've already signed a return offer with a company, but I just got an offer from my dream company and I'm planning on reneging. working at the new company makes the most sense for me in terms of location, career growth, etc so I'm heavily leaning toward that one (not looking for advice on which one to pick). I know this will burn the bridge with HR at my old company, which I've come to terms with. what I'm not sure about is-- how will this affect my personal connections at my old company?

say if I personally tell my old manager I'm reneging (I don't want them to find out later from HR so I've decided I'll have the awkward chat) I understand they'll be annoyed now, but will it permanently prevent me from fostering a professional relationship with them, in like 10 years? what about any recruiters who I was in contact with at the old company? I'm not expecting a super friendly of-course-I'll-refer-you relationship as I know rebuilding that trust will take a long time; I just want to avoid being on anyone's toes permanently. I'm also afraid that the old recruiters/managers might actively say things against me if I come up in a conversation, but I'm being told by some people that this doesn't really happen and no one's going to be "out to get me" just bc I reneged an internship offer. this is stressing me out but it would also be stupid for me to not give the dream company a shot, so any input would be helpful, thanks!

if it matters, the (true) reason I plan to give for reneging is that the location for the company is not somewhere I can work full time, and as a junior I want to intern somewhere that I can see myself working ft (I wouldn't mention what company I'm going to). is that a bad reason?
history.subject: impact of reneging on personal connections down the road
